editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the prindted catalogue to TEI funded by the Rector and Fellows of Exeter College.

msContents.p: Fore- and endleaves: fol. ir blank; fol. iv note on contents, s. xixin; fol. iirv blank; fol. iiir = text, *A; iiiv ex dono, title, bookplate; fols. Iv, IIv–IIIv blank.

supportDesc.collation: 112 ∥ 2–312 ∥ 44 ∥ 52 68 ∥ 7–810 ∥ 9–108 ∥ 1116 (6 + 7–10; wants 16) ∥ 122 13–2312 ∥ 2412 (wants 1, 4) 2518 ∥ 266 (6 is a bifolium, fols. 269–70, mounted on a guard). There are no catchwords, quire signatures, or quire numbers.

binding.p: Sewn on four bands. Standard Exeter binding: simple and quite elegant, calf over millboards, the calf bearing blind decoration of a floral type, early 19th century. The spine is original but it has been removed and reattached; it is elaborately tooled, as is that of MS 33. At the foot of fol. 111 are holes which were probably caused by a chain plate. To assist consultation, sixteen tabs were attached to the first leaves of major items, perhaps, judging from ‘De’ on the tab on fol. 229, in the 16th century.

history.provenance: The volume comprises ten roughly coeval parts, A-J, preceded and followed by flyleaves. Since the leaves of B, I, and J were similarly extended at an early date, they and all the parts between them probably originated in one place and there is nothing to suggest that they were not united soon after. At some stage, however, after the columns had been numbered, some 43 leaves were lost between fols. 86 and 87, i.e. at the end of section F, and as a result cols. 472–642 are lacking.

There is no evidence about the book’s history before it was given to the College (in 1383 according to Rector’s Accounts for Trinity Term in that year), but that it was much used is suggested by extensive annotations and the means by which access to the texts was facilitated, viz. the provision of tabs and the numbering of all columns throughout to ‘1465’ (although this was done with a good deal of error in the way of omitting or repeating numbers).
Titles in a hand of s. xviiin on items F(ii) and F(iv) and the numbering of items ‘1’ to ‘25’ passim in a hand which is certainly post-medieval show that the book continued to be of interest.

Pen-trials with the name ‘Johannes Mortymer’ were written on fols. 1r and 11v at a time (s. xv/xvi) when the book was certainly at Exeter, but he has not been identified as an Exeter man (fol. 1r ‘Ego Johannes mortymer portaba’; (fol. 11v) ‘Johannes mortymer versus. Fert flaue regnant floret ...’).

The gift of the book to the College is recorded on fol. iiiv, ‘Hunc librum dedit magister Henricus Whitefeld Rectori et Scolaribus de Stapeldonhall Oxon’ ad vsum studij eorundem dumtaxat et eorum successorum’ and on fol. 1r, ‘Liber de Stapeldenhall Ex dono magistri Henrici Whitefelde.’ On Whitefeld, still alive and archdeacon of Barnstaple in 1384 and joint donor also of MS 28 above, see BRUO.

At the foot of fol. 1 and on fol. 270v is ‘ES’ and at the foot of fol. 2r are five names, ‘Whiddon’, ‘Stroude’, ‘Hipslye’, ‘Merscer’, and ‘Dod’, in a hand of s. xviiin. Francis Whiddon, John Strode, and Thomas Dod are recorded as donors of plate to the College in Boase1, lix, Boase2, 277, Dod’s gift being dated 1620. Merscer may be Robert Mercer, who matriculated in 1619 and died in 1623 (ibid. 98). For several Hippisleys, s. xviimed, see Boase1, pt. 2, 157.
Not recorded in Ecloga or CMA.
Exeter library identifications are, on the front pastedown, bookplate 3 on which are ‘P8—4 Gall’ (deleted), ‘172–E–4’, ‘MSS XXXV’ (pencil). On fol. iiiv are bookplate 1, and ‘2’.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Exeter College Library.

msItem.title: [A list of the capitula of chapters 36–64 of the Itinerarium of Marco Polo, as in Antwerp, 1485 edn.]
msItem.note: A leaf from another book, probably the second page of capitula, here used as a flyleaf. The beginnings of lines are lost in the inner margin and a good deal of the text is further lost by rubbing.

layoutDesc.layout: One column. 33 lines written on an unruled sheet.

msItem.incipit: Quedam animalia sunt simplices diuisibiles in partes similes que solum partes dicuuntur
msItem.explicit: annorum forte et forte apud senectutem propter multitudinem in amplitudine ossis in quo radicantur.
msItem.note: Unidentified: eTK 1186J = 1187L. The same tract is found in Cambridge, St John’s College, MS 99 item 9, headed ‘Tractatus de libro animalium. Diuisio parcium animalium.’ On the extended leaves, at the foot of fols. 5v–6r, 7v–8r, 9r, 10rv, 12v, are lists of ointments, plasters, oils, opiates, and laxatives.

msItem.incipit: Nota quod duodecim sunt sirupi communes qui recipiuntur in apotheca(?). Primus est Synnel ... Siripus de citoniis
msItem.explicit: ad stringendam uentrem.
msItem.note: Unidentified: 27 lines.

msItem.incipit: Unguentum atharmita magm. relat. ad Alexandrum quo ungiur uenter et ylia
msItem.explicit: Conficiantur et administrantur.
msItem.note: Unidentified: 26 lines. At the foot of the extended leaf is a list of compound medicines in the hand that wrote the list of ointments in items *i and *ii above.

supportDesc.extent:
overall size 253 160 but extended from the original size, by strips of membrane pasted to the outer and lower margins 230 138
190 58
Quire 1 of the volume.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 54 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Anglicana formata, punctuated by low point.

msItem.author: Gerard of Montpellier or
Gerard of Cremona
msItem.title: Summa de modo medendi
msItem.rubric: Incipit summa magistri Guturdi de modo medendi et ordine vnde corpus sit purgandum et quomodo.
msItem.incipit: Cum omnis sciencia ex suo fine et utilitate sua
msItem.explicit: ab umbilico [inferius discendere]
msItem.note: unprinted. For other manuscripts see eTK 0327K and Wickersheimer, Suppt., 93. For a brief discussion of the problem of authorship see Wickersheimer, 204–5.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 45 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: An informal bookhand, punctuated by low point.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two-line red initials, rubrics, red paraphs. Marginalia of s. xiiiex.

msItem.title: Trotula
msItem.incipit: Contra difficultatem partus que fuit constriccione orificii ... [fol. 37vb/6] ... ut cepe pastinace domestice et similia ... [fol. 37vb/6] ... Ad probandum si mulier labore frigida …
msItem.explicit: [fol. 39v] Et cum exierit pista
msItem.note: Parts of the text which goes under the name Trotula, pr. in Medici antiqui (Venice, 1547), 71–80. Because of the loss of the preceding leaf our text begins in ch. 115 of the first tract of the complete text, Liber de sinthomatibus mulierum (edn., fol. 74v/20) which ends at fol. 37vb/6. After three interpolated recipes, the tract De ornatu mulierum, version 3, begins and runs to fol. 39v where it ends incomplete in ch. 214 (edn. fol. 75v/57) despite available space for continuation. Followed in the same hand by chs. 304 and 304a, beg. ‘Accipe calcem vinam sulphur uivum auripigmentum’. For these details see M. Green, ‘A handlist of the Latin and vernacular manuscripts of the so-called Trotula texts’, Scriptorium, 50 (1996), 137–75, no. 76, and on the history of the text see ead., ‘The development of the Trotula’, Revue d’histoire des textes, 26 (1996), 110–203, in which our manuscript is no. 76. Further parts of De ornatu mulierum are G(ix) below. Note that (i) our manuscript having been refoliated, folio numbers cited by Green should be reduced by one digit; and (ii) that our text is in a different order from parts of the text of the 1547 edn.

msItem.author: Ps.-Hippocrates
msItem.title: Epistola ad Antiochum regem
msItem.rubric: Hic Incipit Epistola Ypocratis ad Antigonum.
msItem.incipit: Quoniam conuenit te omnium
msItem.explicit: provocrib’. Explicit.
msItem.note: Kibre, Hippocrates Latinus, XX.A.2k.

msItem.incipit: Nunc quoniam prescripsi
Menstrua deducenda sunt ut bene purgentur
Puluis probatissimus ad cancrum et fistulam et omnem carnem superfluam
msItem.explicit: Tibi defuerit non multum nocebit.
msItem.note: Not identifiable in Kibre, Hippocrates Latinus, xx.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 64 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Written in anglicana, and punctuated by low point.

msItem.title: A list of herbs, roots, etc. for medical use
msItem.incipit: Omnia ea que sunt utilia
msItem.explicit: Explicit id pro quo.
msItem.note: eTK 0990B (this only), and W. Schum, Beschreibendes Verzeichniß der Amplonianischen Handschriften-Sammlung zu Erfurt (Berlin, 1887), 442 (MS Q.185), item 4, beg. ‘Quoniam ea que sunt utilia’.

msItem.title: Alphita or Synonima herbarum
msItem.incipit: Alfita farina ordei. Arsenicus
msItem.explicit: Zuccozaria id est flos agni casti ule salicis marine.
msItem.note: ed. R. Creutz (Berlin, 1940), J. L. G. Mowat, Alphita: A Medico-Botanical Glossary from the Bodleian Manuscript Selden B.35 (Oxford, 1887), 7–199 (which is substantially the same as that published by Renzi, iii. 271–321); eTK 0990B (this only) and cf. eTK 0086I.

msItem.author: Roger Bacon
msItem.title: Liber de creticis diebus
msItem.incipit: Ad euidenciam dierum creticorum est notandum
msItem.explicit: in se ipso ea studuerit experiri.
msItem.note: The text is followed on fol. 50r by diagrams in the scribe’s hand which are part of the text (edn. figs. 2, 3) and on fol. 50v by ‘De modo dispensandi medicinas saponitas’ (8 lines) and figurae divisiones and other medical notes. On Bacon see Sharpe, Latin Writers.

supportDesc.extent:
205 165 Fols. 41–46r: 90 30 fols. 46v–50v
110 65
Quires 5 and 6 of the volume.

layoutDesc.layout: Fols. 41–46r: four columns, 59 lines. Ruled in hardpoint.
Fols. 46v–50v: two columns, 48 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 41–46r: Written in an informal bookhand, unpunctuated.
Fols. 46v–50v: The script is anglicana, punctuated by low point.

decoDesc.decoNote: fol. 50r: diagrams in the scribe’s hand which are part of the text.
Fols. 41–46r: The only colour is red bracketing.

msItem.title: Ægidius Corboliensis, De Pulsibus, with the commentary of Gentilis de Fulgineo

msItem.author: Gentilis de Fulgineo
msItem.title: Commentary on Giles of Corbeil's De Pulsibus

msItem.rubric: Incipiunt versus pulsium Egidii cum commento.
msItem.incipit: Quatuor sunt membra principalia quibus humani corporis
[fol. 51vb/25] Incipit prohemium. Ingenii uires modicis conatibus impar.
[fol. 51vb/40] Ingenii uirorum. Actor more recte
msItem.explicit: Philareti uomeris horret.
Hic metham et opus suum concludit.
msItem.note: pr. Padua, 1484 (GW 268, Hain, 103); ed. L. Choulant, Aegidii Corboliensis carmina medica (Leipzig, 1826), 21–43. eTK 1181I, 0744C; WIC 9332. On the author see Wickersheimer, 196–7, and Suppt., 90–1. Contemporary distinctiones. In the lower margins, in the same hand as wrote notes at the foot of leaves in B*i–iii, are figurae divisiones concerning pulse.

msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.incipit: De urina [Diagram]
[fol. 68r] Vrina puerorum magis dicitur esse subtilis et alba quam grossa quia secundum auicennam pueri non spermatizant quia habent poros strictos
msItem.explicit: Quinque modis diuersificatur urina contenta scilicet secundum colorem. secundum substanciam. secundum quantitatem. secundum figuram. secundum situm.
msItem.note: Unidentified. The incipit, fol. 68r, is preceded on fol. 67v by a large circular diagram, distinctiones, and verses on the four temperaments, beg. ‘Largus amans hyllaris’, eTK 0811N, WIC 10131, ed. L. Thorndike, Traditio, 11 (1955), 179.
At the end on fol. 68v are nine recipes in another hand.

msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.incipit: Dicendum quod omnis urina duarum rerum est signatiua. aut enim significat passionem epatis et uenarum aut uesice et renum aliquorum uero improprie sed in urina tria considerantur
msItem.explicit: tandem dicemus quia urina mulieris spumosa uentositatem significat et declarat.
msItem.note: Unidentified.
Followed by seven recipes, four in one hand, two in a second hand, and one in a third hand.

msItem.author: Nicholaus Praepositus?
msItem.title: Quid pro quo
msItem.note: a list of equivalent substitutes in pharmacy
msItem.incipit: Pro amoniaco signus
msItem.explicit: pro calamento dragagantum.
msItem.note: eTK 1274A. A version of the text is pr. in Mesue, Opera (Venice, 1562), fols. 439r–42v.
Followed by three recipes in two contemporary hands, rubbed and largely illegible.

msItem.title: Ægidius Corboliensis, De urinis (in verse, with the prose preface but without the verse epilogue), and with the commentary of Gentilis de Fulgineo

msItem.author: Gentilis de Fulgineo
msItem.title: Commentary on Giles of Corbeil's De urinis

msItem.incipit: Liber iste quem legendum preponimus liber est noue institucionis
Dicitur urina quoniam fit renibus una
msItem.explicit: presit eam eleuare
circumstancia culpam.
msItem.note: pr. Padua, 1483 (GW 269, Hain/Copinger/Reichling, 100), etc.; ed. Choulant, as item F(i) above, 3–18; eTK 0422D; WIC 4432. On the author see Wickersheimer, 196–7, and Suppt., 90–1. At the top of fol. 71r is ‘Egidius de urinis’ in the hand that wrote a title on item (iv). Contemporary marginalia.

msItem.title: Verses
msItem.incipit: Thetanus omne tenet me cernat.
msItem.note: WIC 19272 (this MS only). In all, 96 lines of verse, in elegaic couplets with hexameters picked out in red. Three other hands, not much later in date, added two, six, and eight lines respectively. The subjects of the verses are noted in the margins: ‘signa critica’, ‘membra officialia’, ‘typus pondera’, ‘typi febrium’.
A gap in the numbers of the columns shows that some forty-three leaves are missing from the book at this point: see History, below.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 55 lines to a full page of commentary, number variable when text is on same page. Ruled in hardpoint.

handDesc.handNote: Rotunda bookhand, the version used for the commentary differing from that used for the text only in size. The text, in a larger size, is written on every second line. Punctuated by low point.
Glossing in the lower margin is in anglicana.

msItem.author: Ps.-Aristotle
msItem.title: Secretum secretorum
msItem.note: in the version of Philippus Tripolitanus
msItem.incipit: quem habebunt in te dominaberis in eis
msItem.explicit: sub hac forma.
msItem.rubric: De epistola Aristotelis missa ad peticionem Alexandri.
msItem.incipit: O fili bone gloriosissime imperator
msItem.explicit: ad extremitatem et eius foramina non multus magna. De facie.
msItem.note: ed. R. Möller, Hiltgart von Hürnheim, Mittelhochdeutsche Prosaübersetzung des “Secretum Secretorum” (Berlin, 1963), 1–164. For the large number of manuscripts, for early and modern editions, and for bibliography, see PAL, no. 81B. Our text begins at edn. 16/11 (ch. 1) and ends 160/20 (ch. 76). Between fols. 93 and 98 a quire of four leaves from another manuscript, s. xiv, has been inserted. It covers the text (with some variations) from ch. 50 ‘et siccitatem’ to ch. 54 ‘sicut predictum est’ (edn. 90/9–100/21) and ends with capitula. Since the text on the added leaves is already in the book and the relevant column numbers in the latter have been written into the added capitula, it may be that the leaves were added for the sake of the capitula. That does not explain why as many as four leaves were added, for the bifolium now numbered as fols. 95 and 96 would have sufficed. Perhaps the recipes added in s. xv on fols. 96v–97r were thought to be of value. They are (fol. 96v) ‘Accipe radices petrosolini brusci … et venenum expellitur’ and (fol. 97r two other recipes and a macaronic Latin-English-French list of herbs. Fol. 97v is blank.

msItem.author: Roger Baron
msItem.title: Rogerina minor
msItem.incipit: Cum medicinalis artis due sunt partes integrales
msItem.explicit: consueuit menstruam habere. Explicit parua summa Magistri Rogeri.
msItem.note: pr. Monza, 1498 (Hain, 4811) etc.; eTK 0317F. On the author see Wickersheimer, 720–1 and Suppt., 263. At the top of fol. 102r the scribe wrote ‘Assit principio sancta Maria meo.’

msItem.title: Medical text on diet
msItem.incipit: Cum omnis operacio medicine tribus modis consistet secundum dicta farmacia et cirurgia
msItem.explicit: parua quantitas eiusdem ru uirtutis nec ci non erit proporcionalis. Explicit.
msItem.note: Unidentified; on diet. eTK 0326M (this only).

msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.title: Signa
msItem.incipit: Finis medicine duntaxat laudabit existit
msItem.explicit: signum est mortale.
msItem.note: At the top of fol. 108r the scribe wrote ‘Aue Maria gracia plena dominus tecum. benedicta tu tecum. Ihesus amen’ and ‘Ihesus’.

part ed. H. H. Beusing, Das Leben und Werke des Richardus Anglicus (diss., Univ. of Leipzig, 1922). This forms the fifth part of Ricardus’s Micrologus; eTK 0561M. On the author, a master of Bologna, d. after 1226, see Wickersheimer, 694–8, and Suppt., 256–7; Talbot and Hammond, 270–2; Sharpe, Latin Writers, s.n. Richard the Englishman.

msItem.author: Johannes de S. Amando
msItem.title: Expositio super antidotario Nicholai
msItem.rubric: Incipit summa que vocatur secundum quod vult Auicenna super antidotarium Nicholai.
msItem.incipit: Secundum quod vult Auicenna primo libro qui in principio practica diuiditur in conseruacionem sanitatis et curacionem egritudinis. Curacio autem diuiditur
msItem.explicit: vidilicet senibus contra habundanciam plantis in membris pectoralibus inbibiti. Explicit Deo Gracias.
msItem.note: Our text is one of a number of abbreviations of the standard text pr. in Mesue, Opera, Venice, 1495 (Hain, *11111) and other early edns., eTK 1423A. It is dealt with by Walton O. Schalick, III, Add one part pharmacy to one part surgery and one part medicine: Jean de Saint-Amand and the Development of Medieval Pharmacy in thirteenth-century Paris (Ph.D. diss., Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, 1997), 286–7. On Johannes see also Wickersheimer, 476–8, and Suppt., 179–80. There are many contemporary marginalia.

msItem.title: Medical distinctiones and ‘Si vis scire utrum eger morietur uel viuet’

msItem.author: Geraldus (Giraud) Bituricensis
msItem.title: Commentary on Isaac Judaeus's Viaticus, in the translation of Constantinus Africanus
msItem.incipit: Cum omnia ex quatuor elementis generata quodammodo sunt agnoscenda …
msItem.explicit: exterius contingentibus.
msItem.incipit: Premisso ergo prohemio incipit a passionibus capillorum
msItem.explicit: consolidare hunc et modificare. Explicit deo gracias.
msItem.note: pr. Venice, 1505; eTK 0325J. Wickersheimer, 203, and Suppt., 92–3. Guide wording for the rubricator is at the foot of each column, sometimes cropped. There are contemporary marginalia.

msItem.author: Gilbertus Anglicus (‘Gilbertus de Aquila’)
msItem.title: Commentary on Ægidius Corboliensis, De urinis
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit Constantinus in pantegni et idem testatur Johannicius
msItem.explicit: Residuum sermonis est intellectum.
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt versus Egidii cum commento Gilberti. Qui scripsit carmen sit benedictus amen. Explicit expliceat ludere scriptor eat.
msItem.note: unprinted; eTK 1483B. Wickersheimer, 191–2, and Suppt., 88–9; Talbot and Hammond, 58–60; Sharpe, Latin Writers. The Ægidius text consists only of extended lemmata. There are contemporary marginalia.

msItem.title: De ornatu mulierum
msItem.note: version 3.
msItem.rubric: Incipit summus tractatus de ornatu mulierum.
msItem.incipit: Ut dicit Ypocras in libro quem de sciencia pronosticorum edidit
msItem.explicit: et decenter conseruent. Explicit tractatus necessarius de supleccione pulcritudinis mulierum.
msItem.note: See M. Green, cited at D(1) above, for parts of another copy. Green notes that a recipe at the top of fol. 228r includes a reference to ‘mulieres gallice’.

msItem.author: Albertus Magnus
msItem.title: Mineralium lib. 1 tract. 1.
msItem.rubric: Incipit .i. liber mineralium qui est de lapidibus. Tractatus primus est de lapidibus in communi. Capitulum primum de quo est intencio et que diuisio et modus et ordo dicendorum.
msItem.incipit: De commixtione et coagulatione sicut autem coagulacione
msItem.explicit: naturalibus inquirere causas ut autem in latina lingua.
msItem.note: pr. Padua, 1476 (GW686, Hain, p. 57, Hain/Copinger, 522); ed. A. Borgnet, Opera omnia, v (Paris, 1890), 1–103. Our text ends in the tenth line of bk. 1 tract 2, edn. 30ª/10. Our manuscript is L.1 in section 17 (Mineralia) in W. Fauser, Die Werke des Albertus Magnus in ihrer handschriftlichen Überlieferung. Teil 1. Die echten Werke (Aschendorff, 1982), 75. eTK 0368M.

supportDesc.extent:
255 165 except for fols. 94–7: 212 135
210 60 except for fols. 94–7: 170 110
Quires 11–23 the volume.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 63 lines. Ruled in crayon.
except for fols. 94–7: one column, 45 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Anglicana in several hands, punctuated by low point.

msItem.title: De lapidibus pretiosis
msItem.incipit: Et per bis binos capit incremente sequentes
msItem.explicit: lunam sentire putatur.
msItem.note: WIC 5927 (this copy only). Ends fol. 236r.
fols. 236v–7v are a palimpsest and nothing is recoverable by ultraviolet light.

msItem.author: Johannes Stephanus of Montpellier
msItem.title: Ars medicinarum laxativarum
msItem.incipit: Ut testatur Auicenna hec est ars medicinarum in genere potencium secundum estimacionem propinquam veritati respectu habitudinis mediocriter
msItem.explicit: de ij partibus olei laurini et thuris et dyalte. Hee precedencia sunt de experimentis P. Hyspani.
msItem.note: ed. K. Sudhoff, ‘Ein anonymer Traktat über die Abführwirkung verschiedener Arzneistoffe aus dem 13. Jahrhundert’, Archiv für die Geschichte der Medizin, 11 (1919), 212–13; eTK 0599C. Sudhoff’s text, not quite identical to ours, occupies only fol. 238ra of our manuscript and is then followed, without a break and to the end of the verso of the leaf, by further text. Running titles at the foot of each column of fol. 238rv suggest that the text was thought to be continuous — ‘de defeccione appetitus’, ‘de canino appetitu’, ‘de irracionabili appetitu’, ‘de defeccione appetitus’. Apparent gaps caused by erasure lead to no loss: the membrane having been palimpsested, the scribe avoided writing on damaged bits. On the author see Wickersheimer, Suppt., 184; he is not to be confused with Jean Pontii, d. 1427.

msItem.title: Virtutes vini
msItem.incipit: Composicio aque vite. que facit hominem letum jocundum hillarem prolonget
msItem.explicit: sanguine inde dificetur igitur sanguis secundum diuersitatem cause.
msItem.note: D. W. Singer, Catalogue of Latin and Vernacular Alchemical Manuscripts in Great Britain and Ireland, ii (Brussels, 1930), no. 1017 (this manuscript).

msItem.author: John Tolet, OCist., cardinal, bp. of Porto (attrib.)
msItem.title: De conseruanda sanitatis
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus de regimine sanitatis secundum Johannem de Toleto.
msItem.incipit: Ut dicit Constantinus in uiatico qui vult continuam custodire sanitatem
msItem.explicit: De conseruacione autem sanitatis isti sufficiant. Explicit.
msItem.note: eTK 1616K. Essentially the same work, although shorter, as the anonymous text ed. by L. Elaut, Osiris, 13 (1958), 184–209, from Namur, Bibliothèque du Musée archéologique, MS 50. On the author see Wickersheimer, 493–4, and Suppt., 186; Sharpe, Latin Writers. Also attributed to Guido Paratus: see eTK 1413F.

msItem.author: Walter Agilon (attr.)
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt iudicia urinarum secundum magistrum G. Agilon
msItem.incipit: Nota secundum magistrum Galterum Agilon. In urina alba
msItem.explicit: et polluciones sunt actuª cretica. Explicit.
msItem.note: eTK 0943M (this MS and BL, MS Sloane 3550 fols. 85v–9v). Wickersheimer, 171, notes our text as one of a number of tracts on urine which are attributed to Walter.

msItem.author: Walter Agilon
msItem.title: Contenta urinarum
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt contenta vrinarum secundum Magistrum G. Agilon.
msItem.incipit: Iste modus est iudicandi urinas
msItem.explicit: Et si sit paucula in hoc signant mortem. Explicit.
msItem.note: eTK 0792L. Wickersheimer, 170–3, at 171, and Suppt., 80–1.
Followed by (fol. 249ra) figura divisionis concerning urine and (fol. 249rb) a uroscopy listing.

msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.title: Regula de urinis
msItem.rubric: Urina Ric. Ricardus Anglicus de Urinis
msItem.incipit: Qui cupit urinas mea per compendia scire hec legat assidue nec oportet longius ire. Circa urinas quinque attenduntur principalia
msItem.explicit: per urinam haberi posse credo cognicionem. hic ergo sit finis regularium congruus.
msItem.note: unprinted. This forms the second part of Ricardus’s Micrologus. eTK 1205G; WIC 15458. On the author and for other manuscripts see sources noted under item G(iv) above.

msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus(?)
msItem.title: De ornatu
msItem.incipit: Faciei decor et venustas non tamen capiti
msItem.explicit: humectando poteris euellere. secundum .S.
msItem.note: pr. Arnaldus de Villa Nova, Opera omnia (Lyons, 1504), 298va–9ra. eTK 0548I. On the author and for other manuscripts see under item G(iv) above. Followed by four recipes.

msItem.author: Johannes de Parma (?)
msItem.rubric: Magister J. de Parma de regimine contra sterilitatem.
msItem.incipit: Regimen contra sterilitatem
msItem.explicit: uero post diu iaceat.
msItem.note: Authorship is uncertain. Wickersheimer, 307 and 460, states that Johannes de Parma is really Hugo de Parma, master regent at the faculty of medicine in Paris in 1272–4. No extant works are known. In a letter, Dr Walton O. Schalick, III (for whose thesis see item G(v) above) tentatively suggests that since our tract shows a fairly narrow use of contemporary sources based on Paris, the author may be Johannes de Sancto Amando, chronologically close to Johannes / Hugo de Parma.
Followed by twelve recipes.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, c. 65 lines. Ruled in pencil.

handDesc.handNote: Written in anglicana, and punctuated by low point.

msItem.incipit: Quoniam plurium medicorum constituciones ultra annum
[fol. 255r/24] Cum paulina datur ptisicis bona non operatur
msItem.explicit: soluit mox anacard
msItem.note: Consists of twenty verses; eTK 0329H (recording the same text in Vendôme, Bibl. mun., MS 200, fol. 3).

msItem.incipit: [fol. 255rb] Si vult facere oleum benedictum
Hoc oleum est de secretis philosophorum
Oleum ad guttum non fuerit in capite
Spongia soporificera sic fit.

msItem.author: Hugh of Lucca
msItem.title: Cirurgia
msItem.note: ch. VII, ‘De somniferis et sublimationibus’, beg. ‘Confectio saporis a cyrurgia facienda secundum dominum Hugonem sic fit’
msItem.incipit: Confectio soporis ad cyrurgiam faciendam secundum dominum H. de Luca.
msItem.note: see E. Perrenon, Die Chirurgie des Hugo von Lucca ... Inaugural Dissertation ... zur Erlangung der Doctorwürde in der Medicin und Chirurgie, Friedrich-Wilhelms Universität zu Berlin (Berlin, 1899), 23. eTK 0245M (this only, not identified). On Hugh see Wickersheimer, 306–7.

msItem.author: Archimathaeus(?)
msItem.title: Modus medendi
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt Capitula de modo medendi secundum Cophonem
msItem.incipit: In medendis corporibus et maxime purgandis
msItem.explicit: quibus proprie ualeant egritudinibus et principaliter et primum de opiatis.
msItem.note: pr. Mesue opera, 1523, etc. ed. Renzi, iv. 416–38. Our text continues for twenty-eight lines beyond the end of Renzi’s text, which ends ‘cum cocleario salis’ (fol. 262vb/3). For the various ascriptions of authorship see eTK 0691A.

msItem.title: Excerpts
msItem.note: from the Antidotarium of Nicholas Salernitanus, following the order of that text but with shorter entries ‘Aurea Alexandrina’ to ‘Trifera maior’.
msItem.explicit: vino sumpto optime stringit. Explicit.
msItem.note: The full text was pr. with Mesue, etc. Venice, 1471 (Hain 11764), etc. eTK 0490B.

msItem.title: Medical notes
msItem.incipit: Johannes Damascenus dixit quod flebotomia ante xiiij annum
msItem.explicit: unde versus Tres tribus in nobis.
msItem.note: Unidentified; brief notes only.

msItem.author: Ps.-Arnaldus de Villa Nova
msItem.title: De visitando (visitatione) infirmorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus de modo qualiter medicus uisitabit infirmos.
msItem.incipit: O medice quando ad infirmum perueneris adiutorium tuum sit in nomine domini
msItem.explicit: expectaris auxilio adiuuari. Explicit.
msItem.note: Pr. in all edns. of Arnaldus after 1504; by Renzi, ii (1853), 74–80; in English translation by H. E. Sigerist, Henry E. Sigerist on the History of Medicine, ed. F. Marti-Ibañes (New York, 1960), 131–40, at 134–40. Kibre, Hippocrates Latinus, 232–3, lists manuscripts and records the variant incipits. For a view of the text, and references, see M. R. McVaugh, ‘Bedside manners in the Middle Ages’, Bulletin of the History of Medicine, 71 (1997), 201–23.

msItem.title: An antidotary
msItem.incipit: Corpus hominis ex quatuor elementis et quatuor humoribus constat
msItem.explicit: uel morientibus difficilis est.
msItem.note: An antidotary, sometimes called Flos dietarum and sometimes attributed to Arnaldus de Villa Nova (eTK 0268H) but also to Johannes de S. Paulo (eTK 0269A); the latter ed. H. J. Ostermuth, "Flores dietarum": eine salernitanische Nahrungsmittel Diätatik aus dem XII. Jahrhundert. Inaugural Dissertation, Univ. of Leipzig (Leipzig, 1919).

supportDesc.extent:
255 165 Originally smaller but leaves have been very neatly extended to full size at foot and/or side and written on by the original scribe: 235 165
217 60
Quire 25 of the volume.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, 46 lines. Ruled in pencil.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are 2/4-line red initials, red paraphs and rubrics.

msItem.author: Johannes de S. Amando
msItem.title: De basibus medicinorum
msItem.incipit: Quoniam ut diximus in areolis nostris. Et testatur Johannes Damascenus
msItem.explicit: Explicit tractatus de medicinis componendis etc.
msItem.note: as identified by Wickersheimer, Suppt., 179. eTK 1308I, this MS only. Dr Walton O. Schalick, III, identifies it, however, as an abbreviation of Johannes de S. Amando’s Areolae: see his thesis (as at item G(v) above), 295.
Followed by two recipes for hernia and one for fistula.

supportDesc.extent:
255 165 but, excepting fols. 269–70, leaves have been extended as those of quire 25 above: 235 165
150 100
Quire 26.

layoutDesc.layout: One column, 36 lines. Ruled in pencil.

decoDesc.decoNote: There are 2-line red initials, line-fillers, paraphs and underlining, and rubrics.
